title: Kamala Harris Campaign Trips
contents:
We wanted to see the amount of events Kamala Harris attended each month while running for President in the 2020 election cycle. In order to do so, we filtered out for just Harris’ events in our campaign events data set and then made a new column pulling out the month from the date column.
We then grouped the events by month in preparation for making a figure to visually show when Harris’ campaign events took place.

# A tibble: 6 x 3
# Groups:   month(date) [6]
  `month(date)` month     n
          <dbl> <dbl> <int>
1             1     1     8
2             2     2     3
3             3     3     6
4             4     4    12
5             5     5     8
6             6     6     8

We then decided to make a bar graph to show when Harris had the most campaign trips out of the year. This chart shows the most events were held in April, and no events were held in September and October.

title: Mapping out DC Landmarks
description: This short project showcases where certain famous DC landmarks are located in the District.
contents:
Our Landmarks Table
Featuring four popular DC locations including the Lincoln Memorial, Union Station, the National Portrait Gallery, and the U.S. Capitol.

# A tibble: 4 x 3
  Name                      Latitude Longitude
  <chr>                        <dbl>     <dbl>
1 Lincoln Memorial              38.9     -77.1
2 Union Station                 38.9     -77.0
3 National Portrait Gallery     38.9     -77.0
4 United States Capitol         38.9     -77.0

Our Map
With the information provided from the table above (landmark name and location), we are then able to create a map using leaflet which will pinpoint the exact location of these places and label them on the resulting map.

title: Company Complaints Analysis
description: These charts and data tables pull out and visualize key elements of a consumer complaints report from 2020.
contents:
Complaints for this analysis were sourced from The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB).
This first chart shows which companies had the most complaints out of the data selected. In order to create this visual, I first grouped the data by company and then arranged the companies in descending order.
After filtering for the top three companies in this dataset, I created a bar graph using plot_ly.
Chart 1


{"x":{"visdat":{"840f13497a69":["function () ","plotlyVisDat"]},"cur_data":"840f13497a69","attrs":{"840f13497a69":{"x":{},"y":{},"name":"2020 Companies with the Most Complaints","alpha_stroke":1,"sizes":[10,100],"spans":[1,20],"type":"bar"}},"layout":{"margin":{"b":40,"l":60,"t":25,"r":10},"title":"2020 Companies with the Most Complaints","xaxis":{"domain":[0,1],"automargin":true,"title":"Number of Complaints"},"yaxis":{"domain":[0,1],"automargin":true,"title":"","type":"category","categoryorder":"array","categoryarray":["EQUIFAX, INC.","Experian Information Solutions Inc.","TRANSUNION INTERMEDIATE HOLDINGS, INC."]},"hovermode":"closest","showlegend":false},"source":"A","config":{"showSendToCloud":false},"data":[{"x":[81264,77386,70075],"y":["Experian Information Solutions Inc.","TRANSUNION INTERMEDIATE HOLDINGS, INC.","EQUIFAX, INC."],"name":"2020 Companies with the Most Complaints","type":"bar","orientation":"h","marker":{"color":"rgba(31,119,180,1)","line":{"color":"rgba(31,119,180,1)"}},"error_y":{"color":"rgba(31,119,180,1)"},"error_x":{"color":"rgba(31,119,180,1)"},"xaxis":"x","yaxis":"y","frame":null}],"highlight":{"on":"plotly_click","persistent":false,"dynamic":false,"selectize":false,"opacityDim":0.2,"selected":{"opacity":1},"debounce":0},"shinyEvents":["plotly_hover","plotly_click","plotly_selected","plotly_relayout","plotly_brushed","plotly_brushing","plotly_clickannotation","plotly_doubleclick","plotly_deselect","plotly_afterplot","plotly_sunburstclick"],"base_url":"https://plot.ly"},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}
This second chart shows how companies tend to respond to complaints using a donut graph to show percentages out of the whole. I grouped by company response to the consumer and cleaned up the data by filtering out blank observations.
I then created the donut graph using plot_ly.
Chart 2


{"x":{"visdat":{"840f34377de0":["function () ","plotlyVisDat"]},"cur_data":"840f34377de0","attrs":{"840f34377de0":{"labels":{},"values":{},"alpha_stroke":1,"sizes":[10,100],"spans":[1,20],"type":"pie","hole":0.6,"inherit":true}},"layout":{"margin":{"b":40,"l":60,"t":25,"r":10},"title":"How companies respond to complaints","showlegend":false,"xaxis":{"showgrid":false,"zeroline":false,"showticklabels":false},"yaxis":{"showgrid":false,"zeroline":false,"showticklabels":false},"hovermode":"closest"},"source":"A","config":{"showSendToCloud":false},"data":[{"labels":["Closed with explanation","Closed with monetary relief","Closed with non-monetary relief","In progress","Untimely response"],"values":[354555,10523,20182,6660,1129],"type":"pie","hole":0.6,"marker":{"color":"rgba(31,119,180,1)","line":{"color":"rgba(255,255,255,1)"}},"frame":null}],"highlight":{"on":"plotly_click","persistent":false,"dynamic":false,"selectize":false,"opacityDim":0.2,"selected":{"opacity":1},"debounce":0},"shinyEvents":["plotly_hover","plotly_click","plotly_selected","plotly_relayout","plotly_brushed","plotly_brushing","plotly_clickannotation","plotly_doubleclick","plotly_deselect","plotly_afterplot","plotly_sunburstclick"],"base_url":"https://plot.ly"},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}
This third chart looks at the number of complaints throughout the year, so you can see which months had more complaints and which had less.
In order to develop this graph, I added a month column to the dataset and grouped by it.
The line graph was also made through plot_ly.
Chart 3

title: Welcome to my site
description: Welcome to Arielle Ostry’s data journalism portfolio. This site is a culmination of the work and skills Arielle has gained throughout her Reporting in the Digital Agee class at The George Washington University’s School of Media and Public Affairs.
